values.description:
Initial layout for the `ign` command line tool.

`ign` accepts multiple commands. Each command is implemented in a plugin that belongs to a specific Ignition project. For example, all the commands that start with `ign topic ...` will be handled by the Ignition Transport library.

Each Ignition library installs a YAML configuration file with the list of commands that provides, as well as a description of each command. Also, the configuration file contains the name of the library and some extra information. You can see an example [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/raw/ign_tool/conf/transport.yaml).

`ign` should work when a new Ignition library is installed/removed/updated.

`ign` loads all the Ignition configuration files and is able to display the list of available commands to the user. If the user types a valid command, `ign` will forward the arguments to the appropriate Ignition library, that will do the work.

`ign` is Ruby!

You can try this pull request with [pull_request_#36](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-request/36/) in `Ignition-transport` (implements `topic list` and `service list`).
values.title: ign tool infrastructure

summary.raw:
Initial layout for the `ign` command line tool.

`ign` accepts multiple commands. Each command is implemented in a plugin that belongs to a specific Ignition project. For example, all the commands that start with `ign topic ...` will be handled by the Ignition Transport library.

Each Ignition library installs a YAML configuration file with the list of commands that provides, as well as a description of each command. Also, the configuration file contains the name of the library and some extra information. You can see an example [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/raw/ign_tool/conf/transport.yaml).

`ign` should work when a new Ignition library is installed/removed/updated.

`ign` loads all the Ignition configuration files and is able to display the list of available commands to the user. If the user types a valid command, `ign` will forward the arguments to the appropriate Ignition library, that will do the work.

`ign` is Ruby!

You can try this pull request with [pull_request_#36](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-request/36/) in `Ignition-transport` (implements `topic list` and `service list`).
summary.html:
Initial layout for the ign command line tool.

ign accepts multiple commands. Each command is implemented in a plugin that belongs to a specific Ignition project. For example, all the commands that start with ign topic ... will be handled by the Ignition Transport library.

Each Ignition library installs a YAML configuration file with the list of commands that provides, as well as a description of each command. Also, the configuration file contains the name of the library and some extra information. You can see an example here.

ign should work when a new Ignition library is installed/removed/updated.

ign loads all the Ignition configuration files and is able to display the list of available commands to the user. If the user types a valid command, ign will forward the arguments to the appropriate Ignition library, that will do the work.

ign is Ruby!

You can try this pull request with pull_request_#36 in Ignition-transport (implements topic list and service list).

values.description: This enables to "parse" the `CMakeLists.txt` file and extract the project name. Relying on variable expansion would make this way more complicated.
values.title: pass string literal to project() to make the project name parsable

summary.raw: This enables to "parse" the `CMakeLists.txt` file and extract the project name. Relying on variable expansion would make this way more complicated.
summary.html: This enables to "parse" the CMakeLists.txt file and extract the project name. Relying on variable expansion would make this way more complicated.

values.description:
As far as I understood, this project does not actually compile any C++ code, so all this check could (in theory) be removed. 

However I preferred to do the least possible modification to the build system and I just ported the related changes from https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/a3fa3d1163cc2fe991ac106e51695b99f8b119ca/cmake/DefaultCFlags.cmake?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default .
values.title: Fix configuration on Windows

values.description:
I'm moving `ign-launch` to be part of `ign-tools`. The first step is to upgrade ign-tools to ign-cmake2. This PR removes the `cmake` directory and updates the main `CMakeLists.txt` file.

This PR requires #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/140
values.title: Updating to use ignition cmake 2

values.description:
[Here’s](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools/pull-requests/13/blueprint-accepting-multiple-paths-in/diff?w=1) a diff without whitespaces.

All paths should be separated by a `:`. Example:

```
IGN_CONFIG_PATH=/home/caguero/local2/share/ignition/:/home/caguero/local/share/ignition/ ign
```
values.title: [Blueprint] Accepting multiple paths in IGN_CONFIG_PATH

summary.raw:
[Here’s](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools/pull-requests/13/blueprint-accepting-multiple-paths-in/diff?w=1) a diff without whitespaces.

All paths should be separated by a `:`. Example:

```
IGN_CONFIG_PATH=/home/caguero/local2/share/ignition/:/home/caguero/local/share/ignition/ ign
```
summary.html:
Here’s a diff without whitespaces.

All paths should be separated by a :. Example:

IGN_CONFIG_PATH=/home/caguero/local2/share/ignition/:/home/caguero/local/share/ignition/ ign

values.title: Accepting multiple paths in IGN_CONFIG_PATH (backport pr #13)

add dummy tools/code_check.sh script that prints an empty junit file if invoked with -xmldir

values.description:
Due to problems of compatibility when mixing projects using ign-cmake0 and ign-cmake2, this PR removes the use of ignition-cmake2 from ign-tools. We could add it back once ign-cmake0 is EOL and ignition collections are free of depending on it.

Actions done in this PR:

* Revert to commit 124 \(before ignition-cmake2\)
* Import pipelines and configure from default branch
* Import tags from default branch
* Use version 1.0.0~pre2 and change tools1 to tools from project name
* Add a note about why not using ign-cmake 

Not sure if we need to backport the docs generation from current default branch. I [started the works](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools/compare/revert_ign_cmake2_import_tutorials%0Drevert_ign_cmake2#diff) but the amount of changes and hacks needed is not trivial.
values.title: Remove the use of ignition-cmake2

Not sure if we need to backport the docs generation from current default branch. I started the works but the amount of changes and hacks needed is not trivial.

values.description:
Prior to this change, all programs started `ign` have process names that are not convenient. Without this change `ign gazebo` has the following behavior.

1. 'top' will either show `ign` or something like `/usr/bin/ruby /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign gazebo -v 4` depending on if you showing the command-line or program-line (this option can be toggled by pressing `c` when `top` is running).

2. `ps aux | grep ign` shows something like:

```
nkoenig  20563 20.6  0.3 1057188 60860 pts/6   Sl   08:08   0:31 /usr/bin/ruby /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign gazebo -v 4
nkoenig  20566  118  1.3 3173704 225480 pts/6  Sl   08:08   2:59 /usr/bin/ruby /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign gazebo -v 4
```


With this change running `ign gazebo` has the following behavior:

1. `top' will show `ign` or `ign gazebo` depending on whether you are showing command-line or program name. I recommend program name.

2. `ps aux | grep ign` show something like:

```
nkoenig  24578 20.9  0.3 1057188 60048 pts/6   Sl   08:13   0:12 ign gazebo
nkoenig  24581  123  1.3 3173708 224964 pts/6  Sl   08:13   1:13 ign gazebo
```
values.title: Set the process title to something nice

summary.raw:
Prior to this change, all programs started `ign` have process names that are not convenient. Without this change `ign gazebo` has the following behavior.

1. 'top' will either show `ign` or something like `/usr/bin/ruby /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign gazebo -v 4` depending on if you showing the command-line or program-line (this option can be toggled by pressing `c` when `top` is running).

2. `ps aux | grep ign` shows something like:

```
nkoenig  20563 20.6  0.3 1057188 60860 pts/6   Sl   08:08   0:31 /usr/bin/ruby /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign gazebo -v 4
nkoenig  20566  118  1.3 3173704 225480 pts/6  Sl   08:08   2:59 /usr/bin/ruby /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign gazebo -v 4
```


With this change running `ign gazebo` has the following behavior:

1. `top' will show `ign` or `ign gazebo` depending on whether you are showing command-line or program name. I recommend program name.

2. `ps aux | grep ign` show something like:

```
nkoenig  24578 20.9  0.3 1057188 60048 pts/6   Sl   08:13   0:12 ign gazebo
nkoenig  24581  123  1.3 3173708 224964 pts/6  Sl   08:13   1:13 ign gazebo
```
summary.html:
Prior to this change, all programs started ign have process names that are not convenient. Without this change ign gazebo has the following behavior.

  1. 'top' will either show ign or something like /usr/bin/ruby /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign gazebo -v 4 depending on if you showing the command-line or program-line (this option can be toggled by pressing c when top is running).

  2. ps aux | grep ign shows something like:

nkoenig  20563 20.6  0.3 1057188 60860 pts/6   Sl   08:08   0:31 /usr/bin/ruby /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign gazebo -v 4
nkoenig  20566  118  1.3 3173704 225480 pts/6  Sl   08:08   2:59 /usr/bin/ruby /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign gazebo -v 4

With this change running ign gazebo has the following behavior:

  1. top' will showignorign gazebo` depending on whether you are showing command-line or program name. I recommend program name.

  2. ps aux | grep ign show something like:

nkoenig  24578 20.9  0.3 1057188 60048 pts/6   Sl   08:13   0:12 ign gazebo
nkoenig  24581  123  1.3 3173708 224964 pts/6  Sl   08:13   1:13 ign gazebo

values.description:
I'm working on bash tab completion, and I need `ign` to output just a list of the available commands. 

The following is my current tab-completion script, which is not done. You can cut-and-paste this script into a file, source the file, and then try to tab complete an `ign` command.

```
function _ign
{
  local cmd cur prev opts
  COMPREPLY=()
  cur="$2"
  prev="$3"

  # searching for the command
  for ((i=1; $i<=$COMP_CWORD; i++)); do
    if [[ ${COMP_WORDS[i]} != -* ]]; then
      cmd="${COMP_WORDS[i]}"
      break
    fi
  done
  # echo "COMP_CWORD[$COMP_CWORD] cmd[$cmd] cur[$cur] prev[$prev]"

  # Get all the available commands
  if [[ $COMP_CWORD == 1 ]]; then
    opts=`ign --commands`
  else
    opts=`ign ${cmd} --complete ${prev}`
  fi
  COMPREPLY=($(compgen -W "${opts}" -- ${cur}))
}

complete -F "_ign" "ign"
```
values.title: Added --commands

summary.raw:
I'm working on bash tab completion, and I need `ign` to output just a list of the available commands. 

The following is my current tab-completion script, which is not done. You can cut-and-paste this script into a file, source the file, and then try to tab complete an `ign` command.

```
function _ign
{
  local cmd cur prev opts
  COMPREPLY=()
  cur="$2"
  prev="$3"

  # searching for the command
  for ((i=1; $i<=$COMP_CWORD; i++)); do
    if [[ ${COMP_WORDS[i]} != -* ]]; then
      cmd="${COMP_WORDS[i]}"
      break
    fi
  done
  # echo "COMP_CWORD[$COMP_CWORD] cmd[$cmd] cur[$cur] prev[$prev]"

  # Get all the available commands
  if [[ $COMP_CWORD == 1 ]]; then
    opts=`ign --commands`
  else
    opts=`ign ${cmd} --complete ${prev}`
  fi
  COMPREPLY=($(compgen -W "${opts}" -- ${cur}))
}

complete -F "_ign" "ign"
```
summary.html:
I'm working on bash tab completion, and I need ign to output just a list of the available commands.

The following is my current tab-completion script, which is not done. You can cut-and-paste this script into a file, source the file, and then try to tab complete an ign command.

function _ign
{
  local cmd cur prev opts
  COMPREPLY=()
  cur="$2"
  prev="$3"

  # searching for the command
  for ((i=1; $i<=$COMP_CWORD; i++)); do
    if [[ ${COMP_WORDS[i]} != -* ]]; then
      cmd="${COMP_WORDS[i]}"
      break
    fi
  done
  # echo "COMP_CWORD[$COMP_CWORD] cmd[$cmd] cur[$cur] prev[$prev]"

  # Get all the available commands
  if [[ $COMP_CWORD == 1 ]]; then
    opts=`ign --commands`
  else
    opts=`ign ${cmd} --complete ${prev}`
  fi
  COMPREPLY=($(compgen -W "${opts}" -- ${cur}))
}

complete -F "_ign" "ign"
